description.raw:
This refactor does the following:

* Puts the rule-of-5 functions in a consistent order.  I choose:

    * Constructor
    * Destructor
    * Copy Constructor
    * Move Constructor
    * Copy Assignment
    * Move Assignment
    
* Replaces the move constructor logic with std::exchange
* Changes the copy assignment logic to use the copy constructor.
* Backports @{557057:f3a199b9-5784-4964-9644-6ef224bc7dc1} 's converter memory leak fix.

In a follow-up, we can remove the `CopyFrom` functions, as they aren’t needed with the copy assignment refactor, but since they are public, there are API implications.

With this, we get a clean test run with ASAN, with the exception of `UNIT_ign_TEST`, which modifies the LD\_LIBRARY\_PATH and disrupts ASAN.
description.html:
This refactor does the following:

  • Puts the rule-of-5 functions in a consistent order. I choose:

    • Constructor
    • Destructor
    • Copy Constructor
    • Move Constructor
    • Copy Assignment
    • Move Assignment

  • Replaces the move constructor logic with std::exchange

  • Changes the copy assignment logic to use the copy constructor.
  • Backports @Eric Cousineau 's converter memory leak fix.

In a follow-up, we can remove the CopyFrom functions, as they aren’t needed with the copy assignment refactor, but since they are public, there are API implications.

With this, we get a clean test run with ASAN, with the exception of UNIT_ign_TEST, which modifies the LD_LIBRARY_PATH and disrupts ASAN.

title: Rule of five refactor
